REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 4 STATE OF NEBRASKA — AUDITOR'S OFFICE To the Honorable Adam McMullen, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. Dear Governor: In accordance with Statute 4847, I take pleasure in submitting herewith my Biennial Report, covering the two fiscal years of 1926-1927 and 1927-1928. The statement of Resources and Liabilities of the State, as required by statute, you will find on page 7, showing resources totaling $73,979, - 763.48, with no state indebtedness. This is an increase in resources of $4,255,277.01 over the figures reported two years ago. FINANCIAL CONDITION EXCELLENT The condition of the iState Treasury is shown on pages 8 and 9. The total cash on hand on June 30, 1928, was $4,479,324.04, or $3,635, - 289.85 after deducting the outstanding warrants. The unexpended balances of the 1925-27 appropriations from Gen - eral Fund, as shown on page 103, amounted to $184,276.76. These appro - priations lapsed after June 30, 1927, thereby decreasing the liabilities of the General Fund that much. The General Fund now is solvent. All the so-called cash funds that used to be merged with the General Fund have been taken out and placed in separate funds. The balance on hand in the General Fund on June 30, 1928, was $890,657.76, sufficient to pay all outstanding warrants and to take care of all liabilities of the Fund. There were unexpended balances of the 1928 appropriations from the General Fund amounting to $146,863.56, and $65,122.62 unexpended Emergency appropriation, total $211,986.18 and this amount represents the total and only liability of the General Fund on June 30, 1928. Against this there was on hand in the State Treasury, after deducting the outstanding warrants, General Fund money amounting to §480,566.25, showing a surplus in the General Fund of $268,580.07. This amount will be augmented by receipts from the taxes outstanding. STATE REVENUES AND EXPENDITURES FLUCTUATING The revenues and expenditures of the State for the two fiscal years ending June 30, 1927 and 1928, respectively, are shown on pages 18 and 21. I desire, however, to call your special attention to the comparative statement appearing on page 41, which shows the revenues and expendi - tures classified for the last six years. The receipts from property taxes dropped from $9,747,580.82 in 1922, to around and below six millions, in response to the low and in - sufficient levies during the years 1923 to 1926, and a deficit in the General Fund was the result. To take care of this, a redemption tax of 1.50 mills had to be levied for 1927, which jumped these receipt* during 1928 up to above ten million.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 5 In 1922 the Miscellaneous receipts, — office fees, corporation and special taxes, auto licenses, receipts from institutions, etc., — amounted to only $2,494,555.76, or about 25%, as compared with the revenues from property taxes. Since then, the Miscellaneous receipts have stead - ily increased, amounting to $8,657,471.33 in 1928 including the Gasoline Tax, and would have exceeded the receipts from property taxes in 1928 but for the Redemption Levy, and are apt to exceed the amount of property taxes from now on. The expenditures for Capital outlay and public improvements dropped from five million in 1922 to around three and a half million in 1924 and 1925. The great increase since then is partly due to the fact the the slack in building and improvements had to be taken up and partly to increase in road construction and maintenance of state roads. The only item that shows no fluctuations is the ordinary Govern - ment expense. This has shown increases year after year, caused by the ever increasing demands for additional state activities. Very respectfully yours, L. B. JOHNSON, State Auditor.
